So that's -- that kind of gives you some idea of the break down, we will have more detail to share when we get together in December.
You are confirming that basically the fair value adjustment isn't the driver of this DRP?
It's not the major driver at '09.

I would say, the DRP is as much of giving us additional flexibility. That's what this is about. Right now at this time, actually capital measures and being conservatively based along capital measures, as you all know. So we just want to have additional flexibility, we have to deal with the St.George hybrids, we'll be consummating the merger soon. So we'd rather actually err on the side of being a little conservative.

Gail, this capital flexibility didn't give you the flexibility to increase the target range. Because if you look at this result, you're the first bank that has actually displayed some of the adverse impacts of proceed with price technicality and this result was going into an environment where asset value are probably even falling -- you are talking about raising loan losses, isn't that kind of telling us that the --.
I think that --

The target level should, may well have to be increasing, because if you look at the history of it for Westpac in particular, the message just keeps on changing. 18 months ago, the message was that Basel II would release a lot of capital, than at the last result it was about cyclicality. This result is about increasing the target to well above the range, I mean, it's just --

I know that, Phil, you're dying to talk to this. I could just see it next to me, this energy that's going there. So, but let me just say one thing. Let me just say one thing. I mean, this is a very different environment from last year. It's a very different environment from when Basel II was first implemented. That's point number one. Point number two, the targets are same with the long-range in mind, and the number of factors that have gone into those. But right now, as I indicated earlier, we want to be either be at the top-end or even slightly above. And because we have a merger coming, we wanted to build an additional flexibility. So that's the positioning. Phil?

Well, I think you've made the point that some other things have changed in the last couple of years as well, Brain, which have also influenced our thinking. So, yes, when we first started talking about Basel II, we expected that that would release some capital. It did per se, but it's been translated into better capital ratios, and our desire to maintain those capital ratios. One of the great things about Bal II is that it highlighted just how -- how much the quality of our portfolio really was, because under Bal I, you couldn't see any of that. Under Bal II, you can see a lot more of it. What's the appropriate capital ratio? Well, as I said, there is a number of things that have gone into it. One of the major things though, is our own modeling through all sorts of downturn scenarios of our portfolio and what it can do to add stress on your capital. I mean you're right. Price technicalities are a result of Bal II, but 16 basis points in the last year is not something that kind of gives us hot and sweaty. We think that and we've modeled what it would be like in the 1992 type of scenario, and that's another 120 odd basis down, if we had that applied to our current portfolio. So that gives you a sense of the kind of extreme scenarios that we've tried to accommodate in terms of setting that target range, and you should expect that, obviously the target range also has a buffer over and above the minimums. The minimum set by the regulator, the minimum set by what we would say, is too low a capital.

But even that, isn't that telling you a range, your minimum should be at least 120 basis points lower than your maximum? Because if you were saying that 1992 would happened, and 120 basis points off your Tier 1, you would actually be below your minimum. Isn't it telling you the maximum should actually be higher?

No. 100 basis points range accommodates lots and lots of different scenarios. And you've called out like it will -- if everything went paycheck back as we did in 1992, you could lose 120. It depends on where we are and what we would do through that circumstance. It's not like we'd be sitting there saying, well, we can see problems emerging and we're just going to sit here and let it all just whack us and cause our capital ratios to drop below the target range. So it's a dynamic thing. The range indicates the kind of capital backing you should expect that we'd be looking to maintain. And the minimum is the minimum and that gives as a buffer. The target range gives you an idea of where in the middle of the range you'd normally expect to see and the upper end says that's kind of where we would be aiming for in the current circumstances.
And then there is the other one, which is that you're actually running higher than that?
Yeah, because we've got a merger on foot and we have the factors of that and we have hybrid rollovers and we don't know the timing of that.
Okay. I'll call it to a close. Good afternoon everyone and thanks very much.
